abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Urban Rehabilitation and
            Management Project for Benin were as follows: the project
            achieved its objectives and merits a highly satisfactory
            rating. The project was particularly successful in meeting
            its physical, private sector development, environmental,
            poverty alleviation and policy development objectives. Bank
            performance is rated highly satisfactory. The performance of
            the executing agencies, AGETUR and SERHAU-SEM and was highly
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the continuity
            of members of the Borrower's follow-up committee and of
            project supervision was critical to the efficacy of project
            implementation. Project implementation was based on
            sustained consultation between the executing agencies, the
            Government (composed of several ministries) and the urban
            jurisdictions. This was ensured by the interministerial
            follow-up committee (comprising all ministries involved in
            urban development issues). Participation of the local people
            in all phases of project activities (from identification,
            implementation, monitoring and evaluation) must be actively
            sought and intensified. Appropriate institutional and
            regulatory mechanisms must be put in place to facilitate
            coordinated land development and management operations.
            Necessary first steps include active involvement of the
            private sector and civil society (associations, land
            development operators, and the like) and the total
            disengagement of the public sector (local and central
            government) from land development.
